content:
##What is area?

**Area** is the space inside of a two-dimensional shape. We can also think of area as the amount of space a shape covers.  

For example, the rectangle below has an area of $12$ square units because it *covers* $12$ square units.  

[[☃ image 1]]

*Want to learn more about the concept of area?  Check out [this video](v/introduction-to-area-and-unit-squares).*

options.alt: A rectangle with 2 rows. Each row has 6 unit squares. The unit squares are labeled 1 through 12.

content:
##Area of a rectangle formula  

To find the area of a rectangle, we multiply the length of the rectangle by the width of the rectangle.  

$\text{Area of rectangle}=\text{length}\times\text{width}$

*Want to know why this formula works?  Check out [this video](/v/rectangle-area-as-product-of-dimensions-same-as-counting-unit-squares).*

###Example 1:

[[☃ image 1]]

$\text{Area}=\text{length}\times\text{width}$  
$\phantom{\text{Area}}=6\times2$  
$\phantom{\text{Area}}=12\text{ square units}$

###Example 2:

[[☃ image 2]]

$\text{Area}=\text{length}\times\text{width}$  
$\phantom{\text{Area}}=7\times4$  
$\phantom{\text{Area}}=28\text{ square units}$

options.alt: A rectangle with 2 rows. Each row has 6 unit squares. The left side of the rectangle is labeled 2 units and the top side of the rectangle is labeled 6 units.
A rectangle with the left side labeled 4 units and the top side labeled 7 units.

content:
###Practice set 1: Multiply to find area

[[☃ graded-group-set 1]]

*Want to try some more area of rectangle problems? Check out this exercise:*    
[Area of rectangles](/e/area-of-squares-and-rectangles)

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1A
gradedGroups.content:
**What is the area of the rectangle?**

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] square units

options.alt: A rectangle with the left side labeled 6 units and the top side labeled 5 units.

hint.content:
$\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{length} \times \text{width}$

$\text{Area} = 6\text{ units} \times 5\text{ units}$

$\text{Area} = 30\text{ square units}$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A rectangle with 6 rows. Each row has 5 unit squares. The unit squares are labeled 1 through 30. The left side of the rectangle is labeled 6 and the top side of the rectangle is labeled 5.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1B
gradedGroups.content:
**What is the area of the square?**

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] square units

options.alt: A square with the left side labeled 4 units and the top side labeled 4 units.

hint.content:
All squares are rectangles.  So, we can use the formula for area of a rectangle.

$\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{length} \times \text{width}$

$\text{Area} = 4 \text{ units} \times 4 \text{ units}$

$\text{Area} = 16 \text{ square units}$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A square with 4 rows. Each row has 4 unit squares. The unit squares are labeled 1 through 16. The left side of the square is labeled 4 and the top side of the square is labeled 4.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 1C
gradedGroups.content:
**What is the area of a rectangle with a length of $9$ units and a width of $3$ units?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] square units

hint.content:
$\text{Area of a rectangle} = \text{length} \times \text{width}$

$\text{Area} = 9 \text{ units} \times 3 \text{ units}$

$\text{Area} = 27 \text{ square units}$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A rectangle with 9 rows. Each row has 3 unit squares. The unit squares are labeled 1 through 27. The left side of the rectangle is labeled 9 and the top side of the rectangle is labeled 3.

content:
###Practice set 2: Count square units to find area

[[☃ graded-group-set 2]]

*Want to try some more unit square problems? Check out these exercises:*   
[Find area by counting unit squares](/e/area_1)   
[Transition from unit squares to area formula](/e/finding-area-by-multiplying)  
[Create rectangles with a given area](/e/find-area-of-rectangles-by-counting-unit-squares)

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2A
gradedGroups.content:
** What is the area of the shape? Each square in the grid is a $1 \times 1$ unit square. **

[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ numeric-input 2]] square units

options.alt: A figure with 4 rows and 4 columns of 11 unit squares connected together on a grid. The top 2 rows each have 4 unit squares. The third row has 2 unit squares. The bottom row has 1 unit square.

hint.content:
The area is the number of $1 \times 1$ squares the shape covers.

 Count the number of squares covered.

[[☃ image 1]]

**The area is $11$ square units.**

options.alt: A figure with 4 rows and 4 columns of 11 unit squares connected together on a grid. The top 2 rows each have 4 unit squares. The third row has 2 unit squares. The fourth bottom row has 1 unit square. The unit squares are labeled 1 through 11.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2B
gradedGroups.content:
[[☃ image 1]] is $1$ unit square.

**What is the area of Rectangle $A$?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] square units

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A unit square.
A rectangle labeled A covers 3 rows and 6 columns of the grid.

hint.content:
We can find the area of Rectangle $A$ by multiplying the length and width.

We can find the length and width of the rectangle by counting the unit squares along each side.

[[☃ image 1]]

$\text{Area }= \text{length} \times \text{width}$

$\text{Area }= 6 \text{ units}\times3 \text{ units}$

$\text{Area }= \purpleD{18} \text{ square units}$

options.alt: A rectangle labeled A covers 3 rows and 6 columns of the grid. The rows are labeled 1 through 3 and the columns are labeled 1 through 6.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2C
gradedGroups.content:
Each small square on the grid has an area of $1$ square unit.

**Move the corners of the figure around to make a rectangle with an area of $15$ square units.**
[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hint.content:
Our rectangle must cover an area with $15$ square units inside.

**One way to make a rectangle with an area of $15$ square units is with $5$ rows of $3$ squares.  This rectangle could be anywhere on the graph.**  

[[☃ image 1]]

**Another way to make a rectangle with an area of $15$ square units is with $3$ rows of $5$ squares.  This rectangle could be anywhere on the graph.**  

[[☃ image 2]]

options.alt: A rectangle covers 5 rows and 3 columns of the grid.
A rectangle covers 3 rows and 5 columns of the grid.

content:
###Practice set 3: Challenge items

[[☃ graded-group-set 3]]

*Want to try some more challenge items? Check out these exercises:*   
[Find a missing side length when given area](/e/find-a-missing-side-length-when-given-area-of-a-rectangle)  
[Decompose figures to find area 1](/e/decompose-figures-to-find-area-1)  
[Decompose figures to find area 2](/e/decompose-shapes-to-find-area)

gradedGroups.title: Problem 3A
gradedGroups.content:
This cat and bird picture has an area of $56$ square centimeters.  The height of the picture is $7$ centimeters.

**What is the width of the picture?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] centimeters

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A rectangular picture of a cat and a bird. The left side of the picture is labeled 7 centimeters and the top side of the picture is labeled width.

hint.content:
$\text{Area} = \text{length} \times \text{width}$

$56=  \text{width} \times 7$

We can divide to find the width.

$56\div 7= \text{width}$

$\text{width} = 8\text{ centimeters}$

gradedGroups.title: Problem 3B
gradedGroups.content:
Li Min measured the length and width of $3$ of her rectangular classrooms.   
The classroom measurements are listed in the following table.

$$ | length | width
- | :-: | :-:
Art classroom | $10 \text { m}$ | $7 \text { m}$   
Math classroom | $6 \text { m}$| $9 \text { m}$   
Science classroom | $8 \text { m}$ | $8 \text { m}$ 

**Which classroom has the smallest area?**
[[☃ radio 1]]

hint.content:
The area of a rectangle can be found by multiplying its two side lengths.

Art classroom: 

[[☃ image 1]]

$\begin{align}\blueD{\text{Area}}&=\blueD {10} \times\blueD{7}\\
&=\blueD {70}\text{ square m}\end{align}$

Math classroom:

[[☃ image 2]]

$\begin{align}\maroonD{\text{Area}}&=\maroonD {6} \times\maroonD{9}\\
&=\maroonD {54}\text{ square m}\end{align}$

Science classroom:

[[☃ image 3]]

$\begin{align}\greenD{\text{Area}}&=\greenD {8} \times\greenD{8}\\
&=\greenD {64}\text{ square m}\end{align}$

We can list the classrooms from largest area to smallest area.

Art classroom: $\blueD {70}\text{ square m}$  
Science classroom: $\greenD {64}\text{ square m}$  
Math classroom: $\maroonD {54}\text{ square m}$

**The math classroom has the smallest area.**

options.alt: A rectangle with the left side labeled 7 meters and the top side labeled 10 meters.
A rectangle with the left side labeled 9 meters and the top side labeled 6 meters.
A square with the left side labeled 8 meters and the top side labeled 8 meters.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 3C
gradedGroups.content:
The figure below is made of $2$ rectangles.

**What is the area of the figure?**  

[[☃ input-number 1]]$\text{ square cm}$

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A figure composed of 2 rectangles that touch, but do not overlap. A rectangle at the top has the left side labeled 7 centimeters and the top side labeled 4 centimeters. A rectangle at the bottom has the left side labeled 4 centimeters and the bottom side labeled 9 centimeters.

hint.content:
Break the figure into two rectangles.

[[☃ image 1]]

Find the area of each rectangle.  

[[☃ image 2]]

$\begin{align}\blueD{\text{Area}} &=\blueD{4} \times \blueD{7}\\
&= \blueD{28} \text { square cm}\end{align}$  

[[☃ image 3]]

$\begin{align}\purpleD{\text{Area}} &=\purpleD{9} \times \purpleD{4}\\
&= \purpleD{36} \text { square cm}\end{align}$  

$\blueD{28}+\purpleD{36}=64\text{ square cm}$

**The area of the figure is $64\text{ square cm}$.**

options.alt: A figure composed of 2 rectangles that touch, but do not overlap. A blue rectangle at the top has the left side labeled 7 centimeters and the top side labeled 4 centimeters. A purple rectangle at the bottom has the left side labeled 4 centimeters and the bottom side labeled 9 centimeters.
A blue rectangle with the left side labeled 7 centimeters and the top side labeled 4 centimeters.
A purple rectangle with the left side labeled 4 centimeters and the bottom side labeled 9 centimeters.
